goals.text: The student can identify and match unit fraction notation to visual representations
example_questions: Select the unit fraction that matches this bar.
This bar shows one part shaded. What unit fraction is it?
Which bar correctly shows 1/6 shaded?
Which unit fraction matches the shaded portion?
Label the fraction of this shaded bar. What do we call one part out of eight?

goals.text: The student can create unit fractions by shading based on symbolic notation
example_questions: Divide this bar into thirds. Shade one-third of it.
This bar is divided into eighths. Shade one-eighth.
Shade the correct bar to show one-fourth. Now shade one-eighth of the other bar.

goals.text: The student can compare unit fractions to determine which is larger or smaller
example_questions: Which is bigger: one-half or one-fourth?
Select the bar with the largest shaded part.
Which unit fraction shows the smallest piece?
If you're sharing a cake, would you rather have one-third or one-sixth? Why?

goals.text: The student can distinguish unit fractions from non-unit fractions
example_questions: Which of these are unit fractions? Select all that apply.
Is 2/3 a unit fraction? Why or why not?
Select all bars that show unit fractions.
What makes a fraction a 'unit' fraction?
Why does this bar not represent a unit fraction?
Is 1/4 a unit fraction?
Select the bar that shows a unit fraction.

goals.text: The student can understand the inverse relationship between denominator size and piece size
example_questions: As the denominator gets bigger, what happens to the piece size?
Why is 1/8 smaller than 1/2 even though 8 is bigger than 2?
Which part gives you more cake: 1/4 or 1/8? Explain.
If we double the denominator from 2 to 4, what happens to the piece?

goals.text: The student can read and interpret unit fraction notation correctly
example_questions: In the fraction 1/4, what does the 4 tell us?
In the fraction 1/6, what does the 1 tell us?
Why do all unit fractions have 1 on top?
What do the top and bottom numbers mean in 1/8?
